Fields.DialogueText: Gneisenau, I finally heard...
...that the inspection team is coming? Yes, I was there, remember?
I do, but you needed to be formally told, hence this discussion.
Discussion? Isn't this more of an informational passing–on?
As if I'm not under enough stress, now you're quibbling over this?
You think you're the only one under pressure?

Fields.MenuText: Under this amount, yes.
To be honest, I hadn't considered it. My apologies.
Oh, please. Just what kind of stress can a Belle feel?

Fields.DialogueText: Well you're not, so deal with it.
Forgiven and forgotten.
Plenty, thank you very much!
All right... Back to the issue. The inspectors are coming soon, so we need to be ready.
So what do we need to do differently?
Good question. We...
Morganas spotted!
@BATTLE
Yes, that's right. Now... Gneisenau, what are you doing hiding behind that bulkhead?
Politely waiting for you to finish with the lieutenant there.
Dismissed. Now, Gneisenau, I assume you're here to continue our discussion regarding the inspector?
I've been giving it some thought, and I think that the best thing we could do is nothing.
I agree.
You see, if we change any of our routines, it'll be obvious to anyone with half a brain...
I said I agree.
...Won't be long before we trip up and make some kind of foul mistake that....

Fields.MenuText: GNEISENAU!
Did you realize you have a butterfly on your nose?
Pardon me, I think I'll come back when you're less of a mess.

Fields.DialogueText: WHAT? What does that tone mean?
I... Wait, what? And what's with the tone?
Who's a mess? I'm a mess? What does that mean?
Oh good, you stopped. I agreed with you even before you started talking, only you're so nervous you wouldn't listen.
Me? Nervous? I... All right, well, yes. I just...
*ALARM*
More later. Just remember next time that I already agree with you, all right?
@BATTLE
Stop pacing!
I'm sorry, I'm just so nervous.
Yes, I know. What I don't understand is why.
It's because we're being judged, Kapitän. Much as I don't like being judged, I hate being judged poorly.
Then I have some bad news for you. This German inspector being sent has a bit of a reputation for...thoroughness.
Like a white glove inspection the Japanese go through?
Not that kind of thorough, the "leave no stone unturned" kind, and by stone, we mean speck of dust. Nothing will escape his notice. Nothing.
And, Neutrality Fleet or no, the bulk of our crew is still German. Our operations are very much at his mercy.
Still not helping.

Fields.MenuText: I didn't realize that was my job.
Good. We should both be nervous.
I know. I wish I had better news, but best to hear it straight.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, you could at least try. So what do we call this mystery inspector?
I'm nervous enough for the both of us. So what do we call this mystery inspector?
Maybe try to be a bit softer next time? Sigh. So what do we call this mystery inspector?
Inspector.
That's what I asked.
And that's what I'm saying. He doesn't use his name in the field, only his title. We call him Inspector. His team, such as they are, are the Inspector's Men.
Simple enough, I suppose. When will he...
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
You know you're not putting me at ease, Kapitän.
Kapitän, he's here! The Inspector is here!
Be calm, Gneisenau. Here, read this.
What is this? A dossier?
A rudimentary one, yes. It's on the Inspector. I thought some of this might put your mind at ease.
You think a few pages will put my mind at ease? Where did you get this?

Fields.MenuText: The less you know the better.
I could tell you, but then I'd have to kill you.
I'm sorry, but I swore I wouldn't divulge my source.

Fields.DialogueText: Safety through ignorance? I guess I should thank you.
I wish you luck on that venture.
Honor, eh? I can respect that.
The important thing isn't how you feel about it, but how the Inspector feels about us.
Well then, perhaps we should go and greet him.
Perhaps we should. Come on, let's...
Perfect timing.
I find your definition of perfect disturbing, Kapitän.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Very unorthodox, Kapitän.
Yet effective, Sir Inspector.
Just Inspector, Kapitän. Were you not briefed on that?
We were. I only wished to give you your proper honorific.
When you say 'I', don't you mean 'we'? Where is the Belle, Kapitän?
I assume you mean me, Inspector?
Indeed, I do. I have a few questions for you.
Inspector, respectfully, this may not be the correct time.
Are you hindering my investigation, Kapitän?
Of course not. Quite the opposite, in fact. You see, as I believe we are about to hear from the intercom–
Morganas incoming. Battle stations!
Excuse me, we're needed.
Of course.
Now that he's gone, what do you think?

Fields.MenuText: It's too soon to tell.
He's clearly power hungry.
I think he likes you. That could work to our advantage.

Fields.DialogueText: Good point. Let's collect some evidence before forming an opinion.
Like the damn Russians. We'll have to treat him as carefully as one.
Don't even think of turning me into a Parisian perfume artist, Kapitän.
Regardless of what we think, we'll have to tread carefully.
My thoughts exactly, Kapitän. My thoughts exactly.
@BATTLE
Kapitän, the Inspector's Men are sifting through our ship like Crassus sifted for gold.
Crassus? How about Midas instead?
Midas wasn't a general in the strictest sense of the word. Crassus was.
Didn't Crassus get slaughtered at the hands of the Parthians?
Well...yes... But before that....
He made his money by hiring slaves and waiting for fires, then buying the property as it burned at a huge discount before letting his men put out the fires.
But he was a general, so I know him. His defeat at Carrhae was a masterstroke... Just for his opponents.

Fields.MenuText: At least we can still learn from his defeat.
And in the annals of history, he will be remembered for his defeat and not his wealth.
Worth remembering, then, is this– in the end, wealth matters little.

Fields.DialogueText: As much as a bullet can learn from a firing squad.
Yet, in the end, his coin spoke better than his sword.
Save to those who are left behind....
I'm...not sure I understand.
Regardless, Kapitän, you heard my concern?
That the Inspector's Men are digging around in the ship? Yes, I'm completely aware.
Do you want me to keep an eye on them?
That won't be necessary. I need you to focus on the matters at hand, for...
Think of the devil and he shall appear.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Kapitän, a moment of your time?
Not now, Inspector. The lookouts are reporting possible Morgana activity.
I'm getting the feeling you're avoiding me, Kapitän.
Respectfully, Inspector, you know how devastating these Morganas can be. There's a right time and a right place. This is neither.
Kapitän, there's Morgana activity... Oh, Inspector. Respectfully, this may not...
I know, wrong time, wrong place. Soon, Kapitän.
Seriously, does he just wait for us to be near a battle before he bothers us?

Fields.MenuText: He's just doing his job.
That sounds about right, yes.
His sense of timing does leave something to be desired.

Fields.DialogueText: So are the Morganas.
Maybe he needs to meet an...accident?
Gneisenau, I'm shocked!
Be that as it may, we... Never mind, here they come.
@BATTLE
Maybe he needs to meet an...accident?
Gneisenau, is it true?
Yes, Kapitän! Someone tried to take the Inspector's life!
This is terrible! Is he all right?
He escaped mostly unscathed, but the bullet grazed his cheek.

Fields.MenuText: How could this have happened?
Maybe things would have been better if it had just....
He knows this isn't our fault, doesn't he?

Fields.DialogueText: It's a good technique historically...but let's not get bogged down.
Kapitän, I feel this is a good time to remind you that the ship has ears.
Fault is like blame, but responsibility stays the same.
Your comforting leaves much to be desired, Gneisenau. Command isn't going to be pleased.
You can't let this consume you, Kapitän. We have other things to worry about.
Morganas spotted!
Like that? Come on, let's go!
@BATTLE
Inspector, good to see you up and about so soon.
I've had worse, Kapitän, believe me.
I've launched a full investigation into what happened. I hope to have answers soon.
Thank you. Believe me, I'll be doing the same. Now, if you don't mind, I'd like to ask the Belle a few questions.
I await your questions.
Very good. Now... Eh, Kapitän, perhaps you have some other duties to attend?
I'd rather appreciate it if the Kapitän stayed, Inspector.
Your opinion is noted. Kapitän?

Fields.MenuText: Thank you, Gneisenau, but I believe the Inspector deserves privacy.
Much as I'd prefer to stay, an order is an order, Gneisenau.
I think you can handle yourself just fine without me. Don't you, Gneisenau?

Fields.DialogueText: As you command, Kapitän. Inspector?
Yes, Kapitän. Lead on, Inspector.
Well enough, Kapitän, though some support would have been nice. Inspector, I am yours.
Very well. Now, as I was saying....
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
And that's all he wanted to know?
That's all he said he wanted to know. I'm sure there'll be more later.
He just wanted to gauge your loyalty to me? As in, to me the captain, or me the person?
Both, I think. He was much subtler about it than that, but his questions kept centering around what I would do if you were, eh, "indisposed."

Fields.MenuText: Well, you are a rather important asset.
You sure you wouldn't rather work with someone else?
Don't be foolish, you'll do as you're told.

Fields.DialogueText: Why are you looking at my...oh, asset.
No, I almost have you broken in.
And you'll listen to what I say!
That's neither here nor there, Gneisenau. About the Inspector's idea....
You know I wouldn't abandon you.
Abandon?
I wouldn't leave you. As long as you're alive, I won't serve another kapitän.
Gneisenau, I... That's....
Morganas inbound!
@BATTLE
Kapitän, I have some disturbing news about the hunt for the Inspector's attacker.
I heard scuttlebutt, but I told them not to bring me in until they have it set in stone.
Well this part is set in stone, Kapitän. The search crews found an M1911 stashed under the torpedoes. It was recently fired.
So definitely not one of ours.
Not a chance.
So the question is, do we have a saboteur aboard, or have we been harboring an enemy spy this whole time?
I doubt it's either, Kapitän. If we've been harboring a spy, I would have known. Remember, I know what happens on this ship better than anyone.

Fields.MenuText: Yes, but you can't be everywhere all the time, can you?
Then it's safe to say you missed something, isn't it?
So you're not perfect?

Fields.DialogueText: What am I, a saint? No, I can't bilocate or more!
Only if one wants to make me feel even worse!
As if you are?
Calm, Gneisenau; stick to the facts.
All right. I... No, it's entirely possible I wouldn't have spotted it if the person in question was careful.
Let's go with that for now and move forward. Assume that everyone could be a spy. Start with me.
You? But that's not possible.
Of course it isn't, but wouldn't a spy say the same thing? Start with me and work your way down. That way, you can be sure of everyone you cross off your list.
But Kapitän, I...
That's an order, Gneisenau.
Yes, Kapitän.
@BATTLE
And there were none of these fingerprints you mentioned?
No, Kapitän. I could send off to Scotland Yard for more information, but they aren't terribly friendly to us right now.
Gallows humor, how appropriate.
Not gallows humor, Kapitän, just bleak. I'm not sure how to handle this otherwise.
I suggest drinking. Lots and lots of drinking.
Kapitän? Are you drunk?

Fields.MenuText: Are you insane? Of course not!
Just because I suggest it doesn't mean I do it.
No...but times like this I wish I were.

Fields.DialogueText: Then stop speaking like you are!
Idle hands, Kapitän; you must keep yours safe.
Well, you can't be. Too many lives depend on your clear thinking. Or as close as you can get.
Sometimes the pressure of command just...gets to me...
Kapitän, I don't like this side of you. We need to keep our focus on the problem at hand.
Which is?
Defeating the Morganas.
I haven't lost faith, Gneisenau, have no fear. This is just a momentary setback. We'll find the attacker. The Inspector and his men will determine our worthiness, and....
Captain, incoming radio transmission. Morganas inbound!
@BATTLE
Kapitän, do you have a moment?
Of course, Inspector. What can I do for you?
I would like to observe your activities on the bridge during an encounter with the Morganas, Captain.
I understand. Please be aware that this is my bridge, Inspector, and on my bridge, my orders are final.
Are you saying I'd get in the way?
He's saying you can't interrupt the flow of orders.
Is there a problem, Belle?

Fields.MenuText: There's no problem, Inspector; it is Gneisenau's place to speak her mind here.
My apologies, Inspector. Gneisenau, control yourself!
Pay her no attention, Inspector. Gneisenau, please apologize.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you, Kapitän! All who serve the Fuhrer must speak freely!
Kapitän, I respectfully decline.
Pay me no... Kapitän, have you gone....
Thank you for your input, Kapitän, but I'll keep my own opinion here. We...
Kapitän, look over there. Morganas!
@BATTLE
Kapitän, I've just come from the galley. Someone tried to poison the Inspector!
This is a nightmare! Is he alive?
The doctor is looking after him now. We'll know more soon.
I just can't believe this is happening. Please tell me you noticed something.
Actually, it was me who stopped him from eating any more of the contaminated food.
How did you know?
I noticed his Porzellan was shinier than it should be. Once he scraped his spoon through the broth, the shiny spot was clean, which told me it shouldn't have been there in the first place.

Fields.MenuText: So you didn't notice anything before that?
Careful, Gneisenau; that sounds awfully suspicious.
So you happened to be the only person...whatever...that could have noticed this?

Fields.DialogueText: Like the responsible party? No, no I didn't.
Letting him die would have been more suspicious, yes?
Unless someone else could detect the reflection of...yes, I'm the only one.
The important thing is that you saved his life. As long as he lives, it should be a mark in your favor.
Unless he thinks I did it on purpose just so I could save him, but no one's that paranoid, are they?
The Inspector is a member of the SS, Gneisenau; they're all paranoid.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Kapitän, can you explain the meaning of these guards?
I'd have thought the explanation self–evident, Inspector. Given the second attempt on your life, they're for your protection.
They hinder my work. Dismiss them immediately.
I... As you wish, Inspector. Gentlemen, you're dismissed.
Thank you, Kapitän. Excuse me.
Well, that seemed interesting.
Which part, the part where he accused me of interfering with his investigation, or the part where he said he didn't care for his own life?
Both. I don't understand a man like that.

Fields.MenuText: Neither do I.
Thankfully, we don't need to.
Don't bother trying. That sort is a sinkhole looking for flotsam to devour.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm glad we're in agreement.
No, we don't, nor do we need to care about them.
Have you been reading the Odyssey again?
At least he's made himself clear; anything that happens is on his own head.
True enough. This whole thing does help me understand one thing better.
Oh, and what's that?
You.
How...
Morganas four clicks off the port side!
@BATTLE
All right, Gneisenau, care to explain how the Inspector's carelessness gives you greater insight into my inner workings?
It's quite simple, Kapitän.
Here is a man who, with the slightest twitch of his finger, can upend your command and career– possibly even worse in a German port– and yet you do your utmost to protect him.
I have to. If something were to happen to him, all the worst–case scenarios would play out at once.
Not if the right thing were to happen to him. Shot by an American gun? Simple to pin that on a spy, find a likely suspect, and hang him before questioning.
Are you suggesting....
I'm not suggesting anything of the like, Kapitän. I'm just saying that it would be easy to make happen, and yet you do your best to keep it from happening.

Fields.MenuText: I have a responsibility to look after the men and women on this ship, Gneisenau.
Life is woven of many threads, Gneisenau. You never know which is tied to yours until it is cut.
I just don't want another human death on my hands. Nothing more, nothing less.

Fields.DialogueText: Then you, Kapitän, are the truest of true.
Poetic. You are the most layered person I have ever known.
Fair enough, Kapitän.
Words from the heart will never disappoint, Gneisenau.
If that's how you truly feel about it, Kapitän, well...
Well what? Do you...
Incoming enemies, Captain!
@BATTLE
What were you going to say earlier, Gneisenau?
What do you think I was going to say?
Don't play coy with me, Gneisenau. You're acting ambivalent, and I can't have that on my ship.
All I was going to say was that I trust you, and that I'd follow you to the depths of the sea if need be.
That's very kind of you, Gneisenau. However, now that you've brought it up...don't follow me to the depths of the ocean if I go that way.
Sir?
Should something terrible happen to me, either in battle or...otherwise... Your job is to remain with the ship and care for the crew.
Kapitän, I politely refuse.

Fields.MenuText: You're to stay with the ship. That's an order.
Polite or no, the ship needs you. Consider this an order.
I'll pretend I didn't hear that. Stay with the ship, that's an order.

Fields.DialogueText: Order or not, if you go, I go.
And politely I say again, if you go, I go.
Pretend all you like. If need be, I'll say it a thousand times... You go, I go.
Gneisenau, we...
Captain, radio chatter indicates incoming Morganas.
We'll pick this up again soon.
@BATTLE
Kapitän, I was hoping I could borrow your Belle for a moment again.
Of course, Inspector, and for the record, she belongs to herself, not me.
Not to hear her say it, but thank you.
The Inspector's not wrong, you know. I belong to the Kapitän and the fleet.
Gneisenau, you're embarrassing us. Inspector, please don't listen to her.
It's hard not to. She's very insistent.
Better believe I am.

Fields.MenuText: Inspector, I tell you here and now that she will follow the fleet and the crew and not the captain.
Inspector, I've done what I can. All I ask for is consideration of my word of honor.
You see how difficult she can be, Inspector. What else would you like me to do?

Fields.DialogueText: You damn well better believe it!
Your word of honor? YOUR word?
You think this is difficult?
Gneisenau....
Thank you for pretending I'm not here, Kapitän. If that's how you wish it, perhaps I should be like one of those Arab Djinn and disappear!
Hmm...this might make things more difficult.
You have the gift of understatement, Inspector.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Are you ready to forgive me yet, Gneisenau?
What is there to forgive, Kapitän? Could it be how you sold me to the Inspector for thirty pieces of silver?
No need to be so dramatic. I did what I had to do to convince the Inspector of our sincerity.
Is that all it was, an act?

Fields.MenuText: Well... mostly, yes.
Well... yes, absolutely.
Truth be told, no. No, it was not.

Fields.DialogueText: Well it was a hell of an act! Do you have an encore?
Who are you trying to convince, you or me?
Is that supposed to make me feel better?
Um... yes?
Uh huh. Well now, if that's your version of an apology, I think I need some more time to think on it. Excuse me.
Morganas spotted!
Never when there's calm. Gneisenau, you're needed at the bridge.
@BATTLE
Kapitän, I believe I have found a way to unmask the saboteur on your ship, but I'll need your help.
The saboteur on my ship? I thought you were here for me!
That's what he needed you to think, Kapitän. It's also why I've been so moody recently...to keep the spy off balance.
So you're in on this? Has your investigation turned up... Wait, of course it has, otherwise we wouldn't be here. Tell me what you need.
Soon, and I can't tell you when, you and your Belle need to stage a very public fight on the bridge. The intercom will be left on so that the entire ship will "accidentally" hear the row.
So your plan is for the crew to hear Gneisenau and I fighting? That's the plan?
It'll work, Kapitän.

Fields.MenuText: It will undermine the crew's faith in us, is what it will do!
And lighting dynamite never fails to destroy the stick either!
No, it won't, not with me at the helm. If you do this, I'm through with you both!

Fields.DialogueText: You tell him, Kapitän! I mean, I'm still for the plan, but this is fun!
Oh, come on! Eggs, omelets, you know the bit.
That's a little over–dramatic, don't you think?
Then what would you suggest, Kapitän?
Here's my plan. We....
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Kapitän, the Inspector wishes to inform me that they've completed their survey and will be making for home soon.
Truly? That's excellent news! When do they depart?
As soon as the tides are favorable. Even better, I was able to sneak a look at the Inspector's report.
They're impressed with your performance, and argue that it reflects well on the Neutrality Fleet "experiment."
So our ideas can permeate German naval culture and expand our influence? Excellent.
There's just one thing, Kapitän. The Inspector wishes to take back one or two of our crew to testify on our behalf in front of Command and the OKW.
Very well. Do they have a preference?
None, Sir, just anyone we can spare.

Fields.MenuText: Well, all my crew is necessary...but I suppose we'll find someone.
They can have anyone they want, just so long as it gets him off my ship.
Tell the Inspector we're happy to comply, only name his time and we'll have the person ready.

Fields.DialogueText: I don't like it either, but it's the right thing to do.
Sacrificing a pawn for a queen... I like it.
I never thought you'd be so happy to lose a crew member... But I believe I understand.
Permission to be dismissed.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Denied for obvious reasons.
Thank you for your help, Kapitän. It's always nice to wrap an investigation up so efficiently.
Agreed. We'd suspected a member of my bridge crew from some time back, but it wasn't until you and Gneisenau put your heads together that things finally snapped into place.
Is that a compliment, Kapitän? I haven't heard one from you in so long....
Go easy on him, Belle; he's under quite a bit of pressure.
And you, just what game are you playing?
Me? Playing?
I saw your dossier, I know what you're capable of, so why are you being so kind?
Hmm... ask yourself this question– am I being kind, or am I simply paying courtesy to a valuable cog in the war machine?

Fields.MenuText: Think before you speak, Gneisenau.
I'm not sure this one's a safe question to answer.
He has you there, Gneisenau. Best let this one go.

Fields.DialogueText: I've been thinking about this a lot, actually.
I'd have to agree, actually.
Oh, but I have such interesting things to say on this.
And....
And... under the intelligent advisement of my kapitän, perhaps I should leave this question alone and simply say, "Job well done."
You've a sharp one here, Kapitän. See that she stays that way.
Of course, Inspector.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Something still bothers me about that visit.
Oh? Is it that he was playing us both from before he even stepped foot on this ship?
Well... Perhaps it's as simple as that, but I don't think so.
Me neither. Something tells me we haven't seen the last of the Inspector. Still and all, he did us a favor in removing the mole from the bridge.
Especially given his next plotted move. When I think of what he planned to do to my boilers... ooh, I just shiver in anger!
Never trust a man too willing to take the crap shifts; they're always up to something.

Fields.MenuText: Elegant as always.
Perhaps we should work on your manners.
Have you learned nothing from your time here?

Fields.DialogueText: You know me, it's what I live for.
My manners are impeccable as always, Kapitän.
I have learned only the right things.
Sarcasm demeans you, Gneisenau.
You know what I mean, Kapitän. The man was a master of deceit.
Sad that someone could burrow themselves so deeply into our crew as to escape notice like that. It makes me... well, enough of that.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
And to think the mole figured out how to strike when you were most distracted during battles.
What's that, Kapitän? Report on the mole's interrogation, I hope?
Nothing so exciting, just reports from the front.
I see. How goes the war?
I'm not the right one to ask, honestly. What I'm looking at is some of the tactics other captains have been using against the Morganas.
Truly? You're taking an interest in the strategy of others now?
You burned it into me earlier, Gneisenau. Now that this mess with the Inspector is over, I hope I can return to my studies.
Hence the reports?
Well, much as I hate to admit this...

Fields.MenuText: ...I was trying to get a jump on this in hopes of impressing you.
...I couldn't stand the thought of you showing me up again.
...I figured I could finally beat you at your own game.

Fields.DialogueText: Aww...that's so sweet of you...and quite surprising, too.
Sorry, Kapitän; I'll try not to be so knowledgeable in the future.
And you failed even at that.
Now who's hiding behind sarcasm....
Morganas sighted!
@BATTLE
What's this, Gneisenau? You're delivering my dinner for the night?
No, Kapitän. This is a treat. A gift. A thank you gift, as it were.
Hmm...two glasses and a bottle of...is that cognac?
I was told this is particularly good. I haven't broken the seal yet, so I can't speak to its virulence.
What's the occasion?
Celebrating the good times while we can, Kapitän. We've been through a lot, you and I, and even though we've only known each other for a short time....
It feels much longer, doesn't it?
Yes, it does. Anyway, I was hoping we could crack this open and drink together not as crewmates, but as friends.

Fields.MenuText: Friends, eh? Of course, I'd like that.
Friends, eh? No, Gneisenau. Belle and Captain.
Friends, eh? I deserve nothing less.

Fields.DialogueText: That means a lot to me, Kapitän. Thank you.
Honest as always. Thank you, Kapitän.
Directness has always been your strong suit. Thank you.
You're welcome, as always.
Would you do the honors?
I'd love to. Where's my...
Captain to the bridge, captain to the bridge...
Ah, well. Come on, Gneisenau, duty calls.
